reviewText:
Early Access Review

Short version:
Buy it if you prefer road racing sims to the more casual driving/racing games. Otherwise it's probably not for you. Also, no ovals currently.

Long version:

General

I'm no native Engish speaker. Automobilista (AMS) is Early Acces, but currently there is no racing sim that could be called a final product. So be aware that AMS and all the similar games are constantly changed, sometimes even introducing new bugs. I'm playing the game for quite a while, way before it came to Steam. The game is made by a small team and it seems that it's more about passion, than big money. It's not about being flashy, stylish etc., but about actual regulated car racing. No offense for NFS players, but this is the other end of the spectrum. It is true that AMS is based on rFactor 1, but it is much more than that.

Content

The game is rather obscure in this regard, but I personally like their picks. It started as a Brazilian Stock Car (which is a real thing) game, so the older content is Brazilian V8s and mostly Brazilian tracks. Over time they ventured into some popular and some less so areas, but most of the cars are quite different from each other. Many current games offer street cars, hypercars, GT3 and touring cars. AMS has Brazilian stock cars (60s, 80s and current), open wheel (old and new), fwd, rallycross, super trucks, and some more. Content is by no means mainstream. I didn't play much open wheel, but generally the cars feel authentic. I don't have any racing experience, but I'm driving probably before most Steam users were born. So yea, the cars feel really different. You sure don't drive the same a Formula Extreme and a Formula Vee. Night racing is supported, but no rain. Dynamic rubbering is on a Todo I think.

Force Feedback

I have a Thrustmaster T500 + TH8 H shifter, so your experience may vary, depending on the wheel you use. This may be the best part of the game. I have all the actual racing sims and my personal experience is that no current game feels near to AMS regarding FFB, especially the later builds. This may be subjective experience, but it seems that the bigger the publisher, the worse the FFB gets (kudos to Codies/Dirt Rally, which is a rare exception). If you have driving experience, in AMS you can actually feel what is happening with the car (Neils' magic). Some of the more popular titles (that I'm playing too) are laughable in this area.

AI

Don't expect human behavior (carnage in T1), but racing with this AI is probably the most you can get if you play no MP. In most current sims, AI is questionable and this one is I had the most human-like races with. Be honest, even in the better ones, the first two laps are miserable. Here you see cars passing each other, passing you. On the other side, I didn't see any human-like mistakes (which I only saw in R3E). I've also been ocassionally divebombed, but no crazy AI flying all over the road or all AI pulled on a string.

SP

The usual stuff. Training, race weekends and less usual, championships. There is no GT/AC/pCars like career. Championships are premade seasons for a car type. It is generally the same as rFactor1, except that the devs sometimes mess with the files and the championships don't really work, which is one of my main gripes with the game. For example in the current build, there are wrong (old) track names in the files and some series have 0 scoring. So without basic IT skills, you're doomed to wait for the devs.

MP

I only play that other game if I want actual MP racing without carnage, so I can't comment on this.

Visuals

Despite recently upgraded, visuals are a weak point. If you don't care about heat haze and sunrays, you'll be fine. But an AMS screenshot is like a photo of England on a regular day.

Sound

I find it that sound can get really subjective. I'm fine with sound in most racing sims.

Conclusion

More for people who appriciate the older racing sims (GTR2, GTL, GPL etc) than posting a screenshot of your purple Huayra.

PS I avoided mentionning other racing games where possible to avoid fanboys which unfortunately are a big chunk of racing sims/games communities.

Early Access Review

If you want a realistic racing experience - one that gets you about as close as you can get to the real thing - buy this game.
First, I need to say the I am a backer in the crowdfunding campaign for Stock Car Extreme, the game that became Automobilista. But there is a reason why I backed the campaign to begin with. SCE is an excellent game and Automobilista is an even better one.

The physics and force feedback in Automobilista are second to none. I was blown away when I first tried SCE and it keeps geting better here. I just did a race where I locked up my front right tire and flat spotted it. I could feel the vibration through my steering wheel for the rest of the race and had to be very careful not to make it worse.

The AI are some of the best anywhere, which, if you play mostly off line as I do, is huge.

The graphics have improved dramatically and yet performance hasn't suffered at all.

The car and track line up contains content you won't find anywhere else as well as some very familiar stuff as well.

The modding community is active and very talented. Automobilista has been out in early access for less than a day and there is already an excellent track mod (Nurburgring)  as well as some skins and a couple hud mods. More are soon to follow.

Communication with the developers is excellent and they back what they sell. They are racing fans who made a great game.

I'm sure I could go on and on but If you want a realistic racing experience - one that gets you about as close as you can get to the real thing - buy this game.

First review i have ever left!

I own/subscribe to iRacing, rfactor 2, Dirt, Project Cars (rubbish don't touch it) and more. My spare time is spent building my rig and racing.

i7 3770
R9 290x
Asus H61 mobo - it was free!
8gb Balistix sport something or other @ 1600hz (limited to 1333mhz by mobo)

Samsung SSD 250gb

With sweetfx turned off and 8x-AA (adaptive multisample through Crimson), this game (sorry simulator) looks excellent. Very little flickering with this high AA and it looks sharp and crisp.

Having played Project Cars that the graphics here really are better! This is because it is smooth. The textures from my view point are also superb! No strange flickering and very little stuttering. Exactly what you need when doing 150+mph.

I didn't buy Stock Car Extreme, because I was put off by the comments about the graphics. Graphics certainly do not mean everything, but I do find, I need racing sims to be sharp and clear with no jaggered lines. I didn't enjoy the old rfactor engine either, graphically or physically.

However it seems I under estimated what Reiza can do. If you had doubts. Don't have. Best £25 you will spend.

I'd rather not have fancy rain droplets and amazing lighting that doesn't work, I'd rather have all the amazing content REIZA have packed into this, how well it is put together and how playable it is. Basic setups are more than driveable and a few tweaks is all it takes to improve your times and start to be able to push. Plenty of Formula cars, plenty of stock cars, TRUCKS, Go karts, rally cross, touring cars, v8's.....................................

and the MODS.................................................AWESOME

- Dev Interaction.....................................................AWESOME

- Community..................................................Only been watching and reading for a week, but so far..........wait for it............how did you know...............AWESOME

If this is what Reiza can do with a 10 year old engine, I cannot wait to see what they will come up with next year.

There is so much more. But you should just click the 'add to cart' button and find out for yourself.

Enjoy!!!

Early Access Review

After reading and watching some reviews and getting the sense this was a well put together 'update' to rFactor 1, with some cars that I've wanted to try (Retro Formula/V10/V12 to name a few) I thought I'd take the plunge. I currently enjoy R3E, AC, and Project Cars, and have found the experience with Automobilista lacking in pretty much every way so far. The much touted FB on the G27 is hardly ground breaking, and the graphics are only just a step up from rFactor 1. There are bugs in the program that result in the Config Tool crashing (which Reiza has acknowledged and a fix is apparently in the works), and the starts are a mixed bag of being suddenly swerving around as the game gives control to you, or a formation lap where the car doesn't actually go anywhere and won't respond to the controls.

I realize this is an early access release, and I'm hoping that Reiza and their team can improve on things to clean it up, but if you watch OnWheelsTV videos on YouTube and get the sense that this is the next big thing in graphics, FFB, and car physics...well...so far it isn't. Of the 4 main titles that I run regularly, this is a solid forth in all of those categories.
